Exponents come first, so you can't apply distributive property before exponents. So he's saying 1^(r-1) * r = r, which is equivalent to r * 1^r, and since 1 to any power is always 1, thefore it is equivalent to just r. Hope that helps

I'm not sure he presented this problem correctly. GPS will be off by a large margin without the corrections of relativity. You wouldn't want a GPS at any point in time to be off by more than 50 nanoseconds or so. When you get into microseconds of error, this translates to the satellites being miles off. Not to mention the difference in satellite and earth time will increase as time progresses meaning failure to correct the satellites will only lead to larger errors the longer they are in orbit.

Yes, it saves time and makes calculations easier. Actually, in real world, one needs approximate results because a nanometer or even a millimeter does not matter when you want to know your location. Only on paper you learn to get exact numbers. In life, close enough is pretty sufficient. Hope this helped :)
yeah but now with the processing power of embedded devices, it's pretty much useless.

at x = 0, e raised to -3* 0 is the same as e raised to the zero which equals 1. so you're left with (1+x)^-1/2, which is 1 + 0 (or, 1) raised to the negative half, which is one over the square root of one, which is one. so when x = 0, y = 1. that holds in both equations.
+DonLicuala  Its obvious because it cancels out the nth derivative of the linear approximation of the function.
or just first 2 terms of Taylor Series near 0
What is Xo??isit X=0

x0 is the point of interest. Not necessarily 0. Professor makes it be zero coz its easier to visualize. In a later example, he makes it be 1.  When you approximating something, your approximation only will be correct in the vicinity(surroundings) of x0. If you are interested in x0=5 in some curve of yours, then x0=5 will be your interest point where you will do approximation and that approximation will be valid in x0=5 vicinity only. That 5 could be a number from your stock market or some video game or gps etc depending on your application.  Correct me if I am wrong though. Thanks
